loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna C. A. O. is twenty-five years old, married and has two children. Her business is located at Kisumu behind Kenyatta Sports Club. She has been selling dresses, trousers and shoes for the last three years to the local people.

She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is that there are so many people in the area doing the same business as hers so customers are spoilt for choice. There are also the challenges of weather especially because her business is an open air market. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well.

She is using her loan of KES 30,000 to restock her business to grow it and to be able to serve more people.  She hopes to open a boutique someday. She also hopes to give her children quality educations. She is a very hardworking and creative lady.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en: Naomi A. has been selling ladies' shoes and bags in Abura for some time now. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a driver and she supports him with the general upkeep of the house. Naomi has received junior high education. Her loan will be used to buy more shoes and bags for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy land to put up a house for the family.

loans.use: to buy more shoes and bags for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stock and sell charcoal

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en: Luciana M. is 49 years old and a sari-sari (general) store owner. He has two children, the eldest of whom is 16 years old and currently studying in high school. Luciana needs additional capital for his sari-sari store business. He is looking for opportunity to boost his livelihood, therefore he is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP to buy additional merchandise for resale.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for his sari-sari store

loans.name: Yawa Felicité

texts.en: Yawa Felicité O. is 35 years old, single, and does not have any children. She works in the Grand Marché de Hédranawoé in Lomé, Togo, selling a variety of grocery products. The busy and popular location of her business allows her to serve many customers in any given day. Ms. O. began her business in 2002 and is now requesting her first loan from Kiva partner, WAGES, to resupply her stock of groceries. With your help, Ms. O. will be able to keep her shelves full and her customers satisfied.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products for resale

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas A. A. is 42 years old, married and has five children aged from 6 months to 9 years old. Her business is located in Kibuye, a busy market in Kisumu. She has been selling cereals such as maize, beans, rice and groundnuts for the last seven years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is delayed deliveries as a result of bad roads. However, she works very hard to keep her business going well. She is using her loan of KES 50,000 to buy more cereals to expand her business. She hopes to increase business and supply her cereals to different parts of the country in the future. She also wants to give her children a good education. She is very determined.

loans.use: Maize, rice and groundnuts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary S. M. is 31 years old, married and has two children, 6 and 11 years old. Her business is located in Migadini Estate in Mombasa, Kenya, the coastal region well known for its many, many tourist attractions, including the Indian Ocean's white beaches. Mary has been selling items such as rice, flour, oil, detergents, soft drinks, etc. for the last one and half years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable. Her major challenge is the number of people in the area with the same business as hers and so customers are overwhelmed with choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business going well. Mary is using her loan of KES 40,000 to buy more general items to expand her business. She hopes to be a wholesaler in the future, to provide her children with quality education and to own a house some day. She is a very hardworking lady.

loans.use: Flour, cooking oil, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Viky

texts.en: Viky S. is 31 years old, married, and has three children. She works in the Grand Marché de Hédranawoé selling cereals and other diverse products. She began this business ten years ago and is now asking for her first loan from Kiva partner, WAGES. She will use this loan to purchase corn, beans, and other grains and cereals to sell to her customers. With this loan, Mrs. S. will be able to help support both her family and her business.

loans.use: To purchase grains and cereals for resale

loans.name: Safari

texts.en: Safari M. is 33 years old, married and has two children who are four and two and half years old. His business is located near a bus stop at Tudor Estate in Mombasa, Kenya, a coastal town that is well known for its many tourist attractions and white beaches. For the last 10 years, Safari has earned a living by selling rice, flour, oil, detergents, soft drinks and other items to people who live nearby. He says that this business is profitable, even though many people are in this line of work, which gives customers the ability to choose where to shop. Space is also difficult to find, and financial constraints have prevented him from expanding as much as he would like. Despite this, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He has applied for a loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more items to sell. In the future, he hopes to become a wholesaler and have enough money to give his children a quality education. He believes he can do this because he is very hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell to his customers

loans.name: Haidie

texts.en: Haidie O. is 24 years old and has one child. She is a fish vendor who works from early morning until afternoon to earn an income to provide for her family's needs. Haide started her business in 2004, and her business income has been of great help to her family in meeting the daily expenses of their home. She would like to apply for a loan of 6,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy fishing nets and baits.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets and baits

loans.name: Angie

texts.en: Angie V., a fish vendor at Nocnocan Island in Talibon Bohol, has four children, the eldest a nine-year-old elementary school student in the village. Angie started her business in 2000 and desires to develop it so that she will be able to accommodate the needs of her family. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. in order to buy more fish to resell.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann W. M. is 29 years old. She is married to a businessman and they have a one-year-old child. Ann runs a beauty salon located in the Central Business District of Nairobi, Kenya's capital. This business is profitable and the only major challenge she faces is that there are many people in the area doing the same kind of work, which gives customers many choices. She also has to work very hard to ensure the success of her salon. Ann has applied for a loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more supplies and equipment to use in her business. In future, she hopes to open a spa and provide other services such as massage. She also hopes to open more salons. She is a beautiful, hardworking and humble woman.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her beauty salon

loans.name: Zeynab

texts.fr: A. Zeynab est née vers 1980 à Bonou, mais vit depuis quatre ans au quartier Djèdjèlayé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à HOUNTONDJI Sylvain, un chauffeur, Zeynab est mère d’un enfant.  Zeynab vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Zeynab n’a jamais fréquenté l’école mais a appris le métier de coiffure. Parallèlement à cette activité, Florence vend des mèches et des produits pour les cheveux dans son salon de coiffure.  Zeynab a quatre ans d’expérience dans ce domaine et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Zeynab est à son troisième crédit à ALIDé.  Elle a bien remboursé les deux premiers crédits et sollicite un autre crédit pour renforcer son activité et pour augmenter son profit.  Elle ambitionne plus tard réaménager son salon de coiffure.
texts.en:
Zeynab A. was born in 1980 in Bonou, but has been living for four years in the Djèdjèlayé neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She's married to Sylvain HOUNTONDJI, a driver, and she's the mother of one child. Zeynab lives together with her husband and her child. The couple provides for the family expenses together. Zeynab never attended school, but was trained as a hairdresser. In parallel, she sells hair extensions and haircare products in her salon. She has four years of experience in this field, and gets her supplies in Dantokpa, an international market place in Benin. She's seeking her third loan from Kiva's partner, ALIDé. The first two loans were repaid without problems, and she's now seeking another loan to bolster her business and increase her profit. She ambitions to later rearrange her salon.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions and haircare products

loans.name: Francine

texts.en:
Francine is 28 years old and is married with three children who are 1, 3 and 9 years old. She and her family live in Gatsata, a region of Gasabo where Francine owns a small shop selling a variety of goods such as cooking oil, cosmetics products, etc. This is her seventh successful year in this business. Her shop is open from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day.

Although Francine has been in this business for a long time, her shop is still too small to sell all the basic goods to her customers. Most of her customers request foodstuffs such as rice, peas, wheat, corn flour, sugar, etc., but she can't sell them due to a lack of enough capital.

To end this, Francine is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her original investment. With this loan, Francine will save for the future of her children as well as reinvest in her shop so that she can ensure the sustainability of her business.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods for her store

loans.name: Janvier

texts.en:
Janvier is 29 years old and is married with three children aged 3, 5 and 7. He lives with his family in the Northern Province of Rwanda, Musanze district, in the village called Gashaki.

It is in Gashaki where Janvier’s salon business is located. He has been an entrepreneur for many years but, although he is experienced in this service, his profit is too low to expand his business meaningfully.

Janvier is requesting his loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of purchasing new equipment, including electric hair trimmers, modern chairs and so on. With these materials he hopes to earn more profits.

Janvier has been in the salon business for twelve years and employs three people from his community. Once the profits increase, Janvier expects to grow his number of employees. The hours of his salon are 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day, even on the weekend, working in shifts so that he satisfies his customers. His business has been well organized for a long time.

loans.use: To buy electric trimmers and modern equipment

loans.name: Nyakabungo Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
Kaguna A. is the leader of his lending group in Rukungiri and appears in the inserted photo at the top left of the group. Kaguna is a married father of two children aged six and four years, with the oldest in primary one and the other not yet in school. He is a businessman who has been selling dry foods such as dry maize and beans from the Kikarara Bwambara zone for four years, and his customers are mostly those who travel to the villages in vehicles in their quest for the foods.

Kaguna has a room in his home where he keeps his stock and, in order to increase his profits, he would like to expand his business to include the buying and selling of other foodstuffs such as sorghum and millet. Kaguna currently needs a loan to buy more maize and beans for resale.

loans.use: Buying more maize and beans for resale.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: Edith M. L. is 44 years old, married and has six children, the youngest of which is only one year old. For the last 18 years, she has made a living selling items such as maize, beans and millet in a busy market in the town of Kakamega. She says that this business is profitable, with her main challenge being a large number of competitors. Transportation is also poor, which makes it hard to take delivery of items to sell. But she works very hard to keep her business profitable, and has applied for a loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more cereals to sell. She also hopes to buy some land to farm in the future, because she is a hardworking and visionary lady.

loans.use: Maize

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: A. Christine est née le 3 septembre 1974.  Mariée à HOUNTONDJI François, un couturier, Christine est mère de trois enfants dont deux sont encore à sa charge.  Certains des enfants sont scolarisés.  La famille vit ensemble au quartier Djèdjèlayé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Christine n’a jamais fréquenté l’école.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Christine vend de condiments, de charbon de bois, d’huile végétale, et d’huile de palme à son domicile.  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Christine s’approvisionne.  Christine a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Christine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et mieux satisfaire ses clients.  Christine ambitionne plus tard diversifier son activité en s’approvisionnant en tissus à Lomé au Togo, pays voisin du Bénin, pour les revendre à Cotonou.
texts.en:
A. Christine was born on September 3, 1974. Married to Hountondji François, a dressmaker, Christine is the mother of three children, two of whom are still dependents. Some of her children have been educated. The family lives together in the Djèdjèlayé neighbourhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She and her husband provide for the family.
Christine never went to school. To support herself, Christine sells condiments, charcoal, vegetable oil and palm oil from her home. Christine gets her supplies at Dantokpa, Benin’s international market.
Christine has already received and repaid two Alidé loans. Christine is requesting a third loan from Alidé to stock up on supplies and to better satisfy her customers. Christine plans to diversify her business by acquiring cloth from Lomé in Togo, a neighbouring country of Benin, to then resell in Cotonou.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy charcoal, condiments and peanut oil.

loans.name: Algin

texts.en:
Algin R., 25 years old, is a sari-sari (variety) store owner. She has one child that is 1 year old. She started her business in 2007 and she has been selling goods so that she could earn an income to accommodate their needs.

Algin would like to grow her business and so needs additional money for capitalization. She hopes to receive a loan of Php 12,000 which she will use to buy additional merchandise.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Sirikatou

texts.fr: D. Sirikatou est née en 1948 à Sèmè-Podji, mais vit maintenant au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à SOHE Wahidi, retraité de la douane, Sirikatou est mère de trois enfants.  Certains des enfants sont scolarisés.  Sirikatou vit ensemble avec son mari et les enfants.  Sirikatou n’a jamais fréquenté l’école.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Sirikatou vend des bois de chauffage, et de la glace de façon secondaire, à son domicile.  C’est à ONAB que Sirikatou s’approvisionne.  Sirikatou a 20 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine et a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé. Les crédits ont été bien remboursés. Sirikatou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’accroître son activité et de mieux satisfaire la demande des clients.
texts.en:
D. Sirikatou was born in 1948 in Sèmè-Podji but now lives in the Sènadé district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to SOHE Wahidi, a retired customs agent, she is the mother of three children.  Some of the children have had schooling.  She lives together with her husband and children.  Sirikatou never attended school.  To meet her needs, she sells firewood, and she sells ice on the side, out of her home.  She gets her supplies at ONAB.  She has twenty years of experience in this domain and has already had two ALIDé loans.  The loans have been repaid.  She is requesting a third loan from ALIDé in order to grow her business and to satisfy customer demand better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying firewood

loans.name: Sinatou Laure

texts.fr: A. Sinatou Laure est née en 1945 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à SOHE Wassi, Sinatou Laure est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés.  La famille vit ensemble au quartier SENADE à Cotonou.  Sinatou Laure n’a jamais fréquenté l’école.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Sinatou Laure vend des sacs de charbon à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Sinatou Laure s’approvisionne.  Sinatou Laure a 20 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine.  Sinatou Laure n’a encore jamais bénéficié de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité afin de mieux satisfaire la demande nombreuse des clients, Sinatou Laure sollicite un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Sinatou Laure A. was born in 1945 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Wassi Sohe, Sinatou Laure is the mother of three children, all of whom went to school. The family lives together in the Senade quarter of Cotonou. Sinatou Laure never went to school. To meet her needs, she sells sacks of charcoal from her home. Sinatou Laure gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has 20 years of experience with this type of work. Sinatou Laure has never before been the recipient of a loan from ALIDé. With the goal of expanding her work and better satisfying the numerous demands of her clients, Sinatou Laure is asking for her first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal

loans.name: Mitala Maria Tusitukirewamu Group, Mpigi

texts.en:
N. Harriet, at the top left of the photo, is the leader of her lending group and is also present in the big group photo. She is 30 years old and married with four children and also takes care of six dependents, all of them in school.

Harriet is a farmer with plantations as well as being a dairy farmer, keeping cows for milk that she sells to diary shops in her area plus to her monthly customers. She is able to make 50,000/= as profits every week and she hopes for this to increase with the coming of another cow since one of them is soon giving her a calf.

The experience of ten years that Harriet has in her business has taught her to be a good communicator and she hopes to educate her children to the highest levels of education. She needs a loan to be able to pay her workers and complete the payment of her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To pay her workers and complete her children's school fees

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en: Leonida L. K. is 55 years old and married to a farmer. They have six children who are between the ages 25 and six years old. Her business is located at Khayega, a busy market in Kakamega, where for the last five years she has made a living selling tomatoes, onions and other vegetables as well as maize and beans. She says that this business is profitable, with the major challenge being that there are many people who offer similar products for sale. But she works very hard to keep her business doing well, and has applied for a loan of Kes 30,000 to buy more tomatoes, onions and vegetables to sell. She hopes to buy her own farm some day because she is a very hardworking and visionary lady.

loans.use: To buy vegetables to sell to her customers

loans.name: La Estrella Flat Group

texts.es:
ESTE GRUPO SE LLAMA LA ESTRELLA FLAT PORQUE SE CONSIDERAN EN UNAS PERSONAS QUE SI LOGRAN LO QUE SE PROPONGAN VAN A LLEGAR HASTA LA  ESTRELLA MAS BRILLANTE. LAS SIETE PERSONAS DEL GRUPO Y SUS ACTIVIDADES SON MARICELA T. VENTA DE REFRESCO, POLLO, JUANA C. VENDE TAMALES, MARIA DE LOS ANGELES VENDE REFRESCO Y UN POCO DE ABARROTES, MARGARITA N. VA A VENDER BIRRIA, ADRIANA BETZABEL VENDE COLCHAS, MARIA C. BISUTERIA Y JENY L. VENDE ROPA.


LA SRA. MARIA DE LOS ANGELES ESTA CASADA Y TIENE 3 HIJOS. LA SRA. QUIERE  AGRANDAR SU NEGOCIO Y PONER UNA TIENDITA YA QUE EN DONDE VENDE ES AFUERA DE SU CASA Y POR AHÍ NO HAY TIENDAS CERCA Y A SI ELLA SE PODRIA SUSTRIR MEJOR Y OBTENER MAS GANANCIAS.  CON ESTE CREDITO VA A COMPRAR REFRESCO, JABON, HUEVO, AZUCAR, ETC. SU META EN UN FUTURO ES DARLE UNA MEJOR VIDA A SUS HIJOS  Y A SI PODERLOS APOYAR PARA QUE SEAN UNOS PROFECIONALES.


HASTA  AHORA ELLA SE SIENTE MUY CONTENTA CON SU GRUPO YA QUE TODAS SABEN RESPONDER ANTE CUALQUIER SITUACION QUE SE LES PRESENTE  Y APOYARSE COMO EL GRUPO QUE SON.  DA GRACIAS A KIVA Y FUNDACION REALIDAD POR VOLVER A CONFIAR EN ELLAS Y DARLES DE NUEVO UN CREDITO Y DICEN QUE NO LOS VAN A DEFRAUDAR.
texts.en:
This group is called “La Estrella Flat” because the members believe if people achieve what they set out to do, then they will shine like the brightest star. The seven members of this group and their business activities are listed below:

• Maricela T. sells soft drinks and chicken. • Juana C. sells tamales. • Maria de los Angeles sells soft drinks and a few groceries. • Margarita N. plans to sell beer. • Adriana Betzabel sells bedspreads. • Maria C. sells costume jewelry. • Jeny L. sells clothing.

Sra. Maria de los Angeles is married and has three children. She wants to expand her business and open a small store that is away from her house. Since there are no other stores in the area, she wants to keep her business well-stocked so that she can generate the most income. With this loan, she will buy soft drinks, soap, eggs, sugar, and other items. Her goals for the future are to provide a better life for her children and support them so that they can become professionals.

So far, Maria is happy to be with a group that knows how to respond to any situation that presents itself. As a unit, the members are supportive of one another. She thanks Kiva and Fundación Realidad for trusting them again by providing a new loan. They say they will not disappoint anyone.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase soft drinks, soap, eggs, sugar, and other items

loans.name: Luzvi

texts.en:
Luzvi P. has spent her entire life on the island of Nocnocan in Talibon, Bohol. She is 26 years old. She was married in 1998 and is the mother of four children with ages ranging from 7 to 1.

Fish selling and a sari-sari store (general store) became Luzvi’s businesses because she earns enough income from it. The income is what she uses to feed and clothe her family.

Luzvi desires to obtain a loan of 7,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy more merchandise for her store and more fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari store and more fish to sell

loans.name: Kavuga Development Group, Mpigi

texts.en: Gladys S., pictured at the top left, is the leader of her lending group. She is a 56-year-old married mother of 10 children who also takes care of 4 dependents. Gladys has a retail shop in Mpigi Town Council that has been in existence for 10 years, enabling her to make 100,000/= as profits a week. Since she is able to save, she hopes to construct her own home apart from the one she occupies with her husband, and this will give her peace of mind. This will be Gladys’ twelfth loan with Pearl Microfinance which she will use to buy more goods for her shop.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: Palmeras Group

texts.es:
Es centro focal de German Busch, que se encuentra en la zona de Huayna Potosí – ciudad de El Alto, tiene entre sus asociaciones comunales, la asociación comunal de “Palmeras”.

La asociación comunal de Palmeras se encuentra en el ciclo Nº2, está compuesto por 8 mujeres y 1 varón.  Su horario de reunión es 10:30 de la mañana los días viernes.  Cuando se conversa sobre las actividades de las socias, ellas refieren que son diferentes: venta de colchas, frutas, comida, helados, discos compactos (DVD´s), costura de buzos y turismo.
Paola Andrea T. F. es una socia jóven de 20 años de edad, ya está casada, tiene un pequeño hijo de un año de edad.  Su negocio desde hace un año es vender DVD´s de manera ambulante, en diferentes ferias de la ciudad de El Alto.   Comenzo de a poco, no hubo un mentor.  Ahora está solicitando Bs.800.- y con esto espera comprar más mercadería.
texts.en:
The German Busch Community Center can be found in the District of Huayna Potosí in the City of El Alto. Among the groups that meets at the Center is the Communal Association “Palmeras” (Palms).

The Palmeras Communal Association is starting its second loan cycle with nine members, eight women and one man. They meet at 10:30am every Friday. When talking about the businesses of the members, they consist of a variety of different activities: quilt sales, fruit sales, preparing food, ice cream sales, DVD sales, sewing sweatshirts, and tourism.

One of the younger members is Paola Andrea T. F.. She is 20 years old, married, and has a one year old child. For the past year, she has been selling DVDs as a traveling vendor through the different fairs in the City of El Alto. She started with very little and did not have anyone to mentor her. Paola is now requesting a loan of 800 BOB with which she plans to buy more merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: La Capilla Group

texts.es:
ESTE GRUPO SE LLAMA LA CAPILLA YA QUE ASI SE LLAMA LA COL. EN LA QUE VIVEN Y POR QUE ESTAN CERCA DE LA ULTIMA CAPILLA DEL CERRITO. EL GRUPO ESTA CONFORMADO POR 13 PERSONAS LAS CUALES SE DEDICAN A RAQUEL, ROBERTA  Y JOSE LUIS A LA VENTA DE ROPA, ANTONIA Y TERESA  A LA VENTA DE FRUTAS Y LEGUMBRES, JARED A LA VENTA DE PLATA, ANGELA, ARACELI, PORFIRIA A VENDER POR CATALOGO, MIGUEL VENDE PRODUCTOS DOMESTICOS, PETRA DULCERIA, GUADALUPE TIENE UN TALLER MECANICO Y REYNA TIENE UN TALLER DE COSTURA.

LA SRA ANGELA ES INTEGRANTE DEL GRUPO DESDE HACE 3 CICLOS. ESTA CASADA Y TIENE 2 HIJOS PERO YA ESTAN CASADOS.  DOÑA ANGELA QUIERE AMPLIAR SU NEGOCIO COMPRANDOSE UN CARRITO PARA IRSE A VENDER A LOS PUEBLOS ALEDAÑOS SUS COLCHAS Y JUNTO CON SU HIJO VENDER BATERIAS DE COCINA, BURROS DE PLANCHAR, ETC. PARA QUE OBTENGAN MAS GANANCIAS Y SALGAN ADELANTE.  CON ESTE CREDITO ELLA TAMBIEN QUIERE COMPRAR OLLAS, SARTENES, COLCHAS, SABANAS SU META EN LA VIDA ES PODER AYUDAR EN LA CASA Y A SUS HIJOS CUANDO LO REQUIERAN.


NOS COMENTA QUE SE SIENTE MUY AGUSTO CON EL GRUPO YA QUE ES UN GRUPO MUY CUMPLIDO Y NO HAN TENIDO NINGUN PROBLEMA Y ESPERA CONTINUAR ASI Y CLARO CON EL BENDITO APOYO DE KIVA Y FUNDACION REALIDAD.
texts.en:
This group is called “La Capilla” (The Chapel), or “La Col” for short, since the members live near the last chapel of El Cerrito. The group consists of thirteen members who are dedicated to various businesses:

• Raquel, Roberta, and Jose Luis sell clothing. • Antonia and Teresa sell fruits and vegetables. • Jared sells silver. • Angela, Araceli, and Porfiria sells merchandise through catalogs. • Miguel sells products for the home. • Petra manages a candy store. • Guadalupe manages an auto repair shop. • Reyna has a sewing workshop.

Sra. Angela has been a member of the group for the past three loan cycles. She is married and has two children who already married themselves. Doña Angela wants to expand her business by acquiring a cart so that she can sell bedspreads in the surrounding neighborhoods. Together with her son, she sells cookware sets, ironing boards, and other items to earn more income and get ahead. Angela will use her loan to purchase pots, pans, blankets, and bed sheets. Her goal in life is to help out at home and assist her children whenever they need her.

Angela says she feels very at ease with the other members and that her group has accomplished a lot. Her group has not had any problems and hopes to continue with the beneficial support of Kiva and Fundación Realidad.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase pots, pans, blankets, and bed sheets

loans.name: Las Amigas De Tlane Group

texts.es:
ESTE GRUPO SE LLAMA LAS AMIGAS DE TLANE YA QUE SON MUY ALLEGADAS  Y TODAS HAN VIVIDO EN TLALNEPANTLA DESDE QUE NACIERON. LAS INTEGRANTES Y SUS ACTIVIDADES SON ELENA E. QUE TIENE UN TAXI, FELIPA C. SE DEDICA A VENDER AGUACATES, DURAZNOS EN LA CD DE MEXICO.  ANABEL  Z., MARIA CONCEPCION R., FELIPA F., ALBERTA A. SE DEDICAN A LA PRODUCCION DEL NOPAL.


LA SRA. ELENA ES LA REPRESENTANTE DEL GRUPO. ESTA CASADA Y TIENE UN NIÑO DE 1 AÑO SE LLAMA DIEGO ALDAIR. ELLA QUIERE INVERTIR MAS EN SU TAXI YA QUE SIEMPRE POR UNA U OTRA COSA  SE DESCONPONE Y ASI PODERLO ARREGLAR  Y QUE YA NO LES FALLE Y ASI PODER TRABAJAR Y SACAR MAS GANANCIAS.


CON ESTE CREDITO QUIERE COMPRAR ACEITES, ANTICONGELANTES, LLANTAS, REFACCIONES. LA META QUE ELLA TIENE A FUTURO ES SALIR ADELANTE JUNTO CON SU ESPOSO PARA PODER DARLE A SU HIJO LO QUE NECECITE.
ELENA NOS COMENTA QUE SE SIENTE MUY AGUSTO CON SU GRUPO YA QUE SE CONOCEN DESDE HACE MUCHO TIEMPO Y SE SIENTEN CONTENTAS DE QUE EXISTAN EMPRESAS COMO KIVA Y FUNDACION REALIDAD  PARA AYUDAR A LAS PERSONAS A SACAR SU NEGOCIO ADELANTE.
texts.en:
This group is called “Las Amigas de Tlane” (The Friends of Tlane) because they are close-knit and have all lived in Tlanepantla since birth. The members are involved in the following business activities:

• Elena E. has a taxi. • Felipa C. sells avocados and peaches in Mexico City. • Anabel Z., Maria Concepcion R., Felipa F., and Alberta A. prepare “nopales” (the edible leaves of the prickly pear cactus).

Sra. Elena is the group representative. She is married and has a one year old son named Diego Aldair. Elena wants to invest more into her taxi because there is always one thing or another that keeps breaking down. She wants to make repairs so that it keeps operating and she can continue to generate more revenue. With her loan, Elena will buy motor oil, antifreeze, tires, and spare parts. Her goal is to get ahead along with her husband so that they can provide everything that her son needs. She says she feels very at ease with the other members because she has known them for a long time.

Elena is pleased that organizations such as Kiva and Fundación Realidad exist to help people succeed in their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase motor oil, antifreeze, tires, and spare parts

loans.name: Kamu Kamu Group 1, Kayunga

texts.en: Appearing in the small photo is K. Ben. He is part of the big group and the leader of the same group in Kayunga. Ben is 32 years old and married with 4 children, all in primary school, as he takes care of three dependents. He has had a retail shop for 4 years where he sells general merchandise from the Seeta-Nyize zone, and from his sales he is able to make 60,000 as weekly profits. Ben is a friendly and very devoted man, and he would like to expand his shop into wholesale so that he could earn a lot for his children’s school fees and future development.

loans.use: To buy general merchandise for his shop and pay his children's school fees

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en: Angelita O. buys coconut wine from Leyte. She then sells the wine and earns Php 200.00 per container, income which really helps her family to purchase adequate supplies of food, clothing and other needs.  Angelita is now requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. which she will use to buy more coconut wine to resell.

loans.use: To buy more coconut wine to resell

loans.name: Kamu Kamu Group 2, Kayunga

texts.en: K. Nansubuga, in the small photo, is the leader of her lending group in Kayunga. She is 47 years old and married with 7 children, of whom two are at the university and five are in secondary school as she takes care of 5 grandchildren. Nansubuga is a business lady who has been involved in the sale of produce like matooke, cassava, and sweet potatoes from Kungu-Kavule for 10 years, and she is able to make 60,000 in profit a week. She is a very friendly lady, and this has won her more customers. Nansubuga has a plan of beginning to offload a truck full of matooke for sale, since the experience she has in business shows that matooke are more marketable than other produce in her area because it is rarely grown, unlike other crops. She needs a loan to be able buy more produce for resale.

loans.use: To buy more matooke, sweet potatoes, and cassava for resale

loans.name: Dieudonne

texts.en:
Dieudonne is 25 years old and is still single. He lives with his parents in Nyarugenge district, one of the districts of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. He owns an Internet cafe business and is a young man in this field because he has been an entrepreneur only since 2009.

Dieudonne is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance in order to expand his business. He will use the loan to purchase more computers to be used in his business and other materials such as chairs and so on.

Dieudonne is a hardworking man. His business is well organized and he is able to employ one person as a helper. The hours of his business are from eight in the morning to ten in the evening every day, even during the weekend. With this loan, he will be able to obtain more profits, which will help him to get married in the future.

loans.use: To buy more computers for his Internet café

loans.name: José

texts.es:
José, tiene 49 años y tiene dos hijos (José de 21 años y Karen de 11 años).  José es periodista y trabaja en una radio local llamada Santa Mónica por horas, ya son 20 años que se dedica al periodismo. Nuestro socio es un padre trabajador y emprendedor que a parte de ser periodista se dedica al mantenimiento de inmuebles, él trabaja con varios empleados en obras que le contratan, por ejemplo ellos hacen enchapados de mayólicas, refacción de paredes, etc. José requiere el préstamo para pagar los sueltos de sus empleados porque José tiene un contrato para realizar una obra pero los dueños de la obra pagaran al finalizar la obra. 
  
El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.

(La ciudad de Pucyura es distrito de la ciudad de Anta del Departamento del Cusco, Pucyura se encuentra ubicada a 40 minutos de la ciudad de Cusco).
texts.en:
José, 49, has two children (José, 21 and Karen, 11). José is a journalist and works hours at a local radio station called, Santa Mónica. He has been a journalist for 20 years. He is a hard-working father who, besides being a jounalist, also provides building maintenance services. He has several employees and they are hired to do jobs like: applying veneers, wall repairs, etc. José needs financing to pay his employees because he has a work order pending but he won't get paid for it until it is completed. He is grateful for the opportunity offered by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion. (Pucyura is a district of the city of Anta, Cusco department and is located 40 minutes away from the city of Cusco)

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay employee salaries.

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es:
En el Banco Comunal Alianza está localizado en la ciudadela Nuevo Portoviejo en la Provincia  de Manabí  aquí conversamos con la señora Alejandrina ella  está casada tiene 4 hijos, es ama de casa pero también es comerciante, lleva  varios años dedicando parte de su tiempo a la venta de productos de bazar, papelería y ropa, además de variar los productos según la temporada  con el dinero que recibirá del crédito solicitado a la Fundación invertirá en ropa de temporada playera como ternos de baño, sandalias, toallas,  batas y más, su  esposo es el encargado de recorrer  otras ciudades y balnearios de la provincia.

Para surtir su negocio Alejandrina viaja  a la ciudad de Guayaquil para comprar  a los mayoristas  esto les deja buenas ganancias y gracias a ello han logrado dar el  estudio a sus hijos y llevar una vida tranquila.

El sueño de Alejandrina es  tener un su casa un bazar para ella quedarse ahí mientras que su esposo sale todos los días muy temprano y ella dedicarse un poco más a sus hijos y las actividades del hogar.
texts.en:
The Alianza Communal Bank is located in the Nuevo Portoviejo tenement in the Manabí province. We are here talking with Alejandrina. She is married and has four children. She is a housewife, but she is also a businesswoman. For several years she has worked part-time selling bazaar products, stationery, and clothes. She varies the products according to the season. She will use the money she will get from the loan she has requested from the Foundation to invest in clothes for the beach season. She will buy things like bathing suits, sandals, towels, robes, and more. Her husband is the one who travels to other cities and recreational areas in the province. In order to stock her store, Alejandrina travels to the city of Guayaquil to buy from the wholesalers. This leaves her good earnings. Thanks to the earnings she has been able to give her children an education and have a peaceful life. Alejandrina’s dream is to have a bazaar in her house so that she can stay there while her husband leaves very early everyday. Then she could devote herself to her children and the household activities a little more.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bathing suits, robes, sandals, and towels, etc. for the beach season

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en: Rosa A. is working very hard to become the best mother to her only child. A fish-seller since 2000, she retails an average of 10-15 kilos everyday.  Because it is a very good business, Rosa seeks to improve her revenue and is therefore requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy more fish to resell.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell

loans.name: Tarimaya

texts.en:
Mrs. TariMaya D., a resident of Chappagaun, lives with her husband and two sons. Chappagaun is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur, and most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Her husband works in a private office. Her older son has a small business, and her younger son is in grade 11.

Mrs. D. is engaged in goat farming. At this time she has five goats on her farm, and she sells the goats in the local market. This business helps her contribute something to improve the living standard of her family. Now she is requesting a loan of Rs. 30,000 to buy a few more goats and grain to feed them.

loans.use: To buy baby goats

loans.name: Esmeralda Group

texts.es:
La asociación comunal Esmeralda se encuentra el el ciclo Nº14, es decir que ya tiene como siete años formando parte del Centro Focal de German Busch.  Son once integrantes, 10 mujeres y un varon.
Los negocios de los integrantes de la asociación van desde venta de celulares, venta de comida, frituras (papas fritas), tejidos a máquina, venta de abarrotes, venta de ropa, artesanía en ropa, ropa, tejido de alfombras.

En el caso de la presidenta, la señora Margot G. de 40 años de edad, ella tiene el negocio de venta de celulares desde hace unos diez años.  Cuando se le pregunta de cómo se animó a iniciar ese negocio, ella dice que era necesario, pues tenìa muchos hijos (4 varones y 2 mujeres).  Actualmente continua con la compra – venta de celulares con el apoyo de su esposo, en las diferentes ferias del la ciudad de El Alto.
texts.en:
The Esmeralda communal bank is in its 14th loan cycle; that is, it has been part of the German Busch Focal Center for about 7 years. It has 11 members, 10 women and one man. They are engaged in a wide range of commercial enterprises, such as: the sale of cell phones, food, French fries, machine-woven articles, grocery sales, clothing sales, craftsmaking, rug weaving. The group president, Margot Gonzalez, 40, is a case in particular. She has sold cell phones for about 10 years now. When she was asked what motivated her to go into this line of work, she stated that it was necessary because she had many children (4 boys and 2 girls). Currently, she continues as a cell phone merchant, together with her husband, in the various markets in the city of El Alto.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For semi-new and new cell phones.

loans.name: Thikay Maya

texts.en:
Mrs. Thikay Maya D. is a farmer in the village of Chapagaun. She owns a piece of land where she grows green vegetables. She sells her vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening daily. This business helps her contribute something to improve the living standard of her family. Now she is requesting a loan of Rs 25,000 to buy seeds and fertilizers for her agricultural farming.

Mrs. D. lives with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Ram Bhai D., is also a farmer. She has one daughter and one son. Her daughter is studying in grade nine and her son is studying in grade four.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Normita

texts.en:
Normita C.’ livelihood is fishing. She has four children, her eldest child being 9 years old and currently studying in elementary school.

Normita started her business in 2000. She desires to improve her livelihood by buying fishing materials like nets and bait. If she gets her loan, she will also start to buy additional fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy fishing materials like nets and bait and to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Lila

texts.en:
Mrs. Lila D. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Chapagaun, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband and one son. Her husband is a driver and her son studies in primary school.

Mrs. D. opened her grocery store five years ago to improve the economic condition of her family. In her shop she sells various grocery items such as rice, maize, noodles, snacks, etc. With her shop income she fulfills the needs of her family.

Now Mrs. D. is requesting an Rs 30,000 loan to invest in her shop.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her shop

loans.name: Dembe Development Group, Kayunga

texts.en:
L. Rukia, shown in the small photo as well as in the big photo, is the leader of her lending group in Kayunga. She is a friendly and very hardworking lady with a restaurant business in Kayunga town that she has owned for over five years.

Over the years, she has seen her restaurant grow from a very small restaurant to its current state where she is even able to sell cold drinks like sodas and juice and water to her customers. She prepares breakfast, lunch and supper and  she has a large number of customers that come because of her cooking skills and her good customer care.

Rukia needs a loan to be able to stock more foodstuffs and drinks for her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and drinks for her restaurant

loans.name: Rolando

texts.es:
Rolando tiene 38 años de edad, es casado y vive junto a sus cuatro hijos en el distrito de Cayaltí. Ubicado a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a brindar servicio de transporte de carga y pasajeros en su mototaxi. El nos comenta que adquirió su vehículo gracias al dinero que logró ahorrar de su negocio de crianza y venta de animales. El trabaja en su vehículo durante todo el dia y cubre rutas dentro de la ciudad de Cayaltí y sus caseríos.

Eventualmente se dedica a la venta de embutidos en el mercado de la ciudad de Cayaltí. Estas actividades le sirven para solventar los gastos familiares y sacar adelante a los suyos.

El contínuo uso otorgado a su unidad móvil ha hecho que esta empiece a sufrir algunas fallas que requieren de urgente reparación, por lo que se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en la reparación y mantenimiento de su mototaxi.

Rolando es una persona bastante responsable y trabajadora. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Rolando, 38, is married and lives with his four children in Cayaltí district, which is an hour away from the city of Chiclayo. He provides passenger and cargo transportation services as a mototaxi driver. He tells us that he got his vehicle thanks to money he was able to save up from raising and selling animals. He works in his vehicle all day and covers routes within the city of Cayaltí and its surrounding settlements. Occasionally he sells cured meats in Cayaltí's market. These activities make it possible for him to meet family expenses and to move his family ahead in life. The constant use of his vehicle has caused it to begin to need service and repair. He is asking Edpyme Alternativa for a 2000 new sol loan to invest in service and repair of his mototaxi. Rolando is quite a responsible and hard-working person. He has collaborated previously with our institution and has shown punctuality and responsibility with respect to his repayment obligations.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For mototaxi service and repair.

loans.name: Shiddi

texts.en:
Mrs. Shiddi D. is a farmer in the village of Chapagaun, lalitpur. She owns a piece of land where she grows green vegetables. She sells her vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening and uses her income in fulfilling the needs of her family.

Now Mrs. D. is requesting her first loan of Rs 10,000 to buy seeds and fertilizer for her agricultural work.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Ganga

texts.en: Mrs. Ganga D. lives in Chappagaun. To improve her standard of living, she opened a grocery shop five years ago. She sells different items, such as noodles, rice, and biscuits (cookies). The demand for grocery goods is increasing in her area, so Mrs. D. is requesting her second loan from Kiva (Click here to see her first loan). She seeks a loan to buy grocery goods to meet the demand. Mrs. D. is very grateful for your support. She will use her income to provide a better education for her children.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel A. is a piggery owner. She raises pigs and sells the meat at the supermarket. She bought a stall and is able to market meat to a lot of customers. She is also supplying meat to popular restaurants and canteens in Talibon, Bohol.

Maribel’s father was confined with diabetes. Some portion of her savings were used to pay his medications that reached more than Php 100,000. Her business is what sustains her family. She wants to apply for a loan of Php 50,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI) to continue her business.


CEVI is helping its clients not just during the early stages of their business. It continues to support its clients who accomplish more in the later stages of their businesses because the businesses help create more jobs or employment in the community.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Sarmila

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarmila P. lives in Bhakapati. To improve her standard of living, she opened a grocery shop five years ago where she sells different items, such as noodles, rice, and biscuits (cookies).

The demand for grocery goods is increasing in her area, so Mrs. P. is requesting her first loan from Kiva. She seeks a loan to buy grocery goods to meet the demand. She is very grateful for your support. She will use her income to provide a better education for her children.

Mrs. P. lives with her husband and three children. She has one son and two daughters. Her older daughter is studying in university and her younger daughter is studying in grade 11. Her son is studying in grade 8.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Miralyn

texts.en:
Miralyn and her family rely on farming. She said that they are able to eat because of the rice farm that she and her husband till and their other needs are also met through her income from the farm. She does her best to maintain the farm and hopefully make it grow.

Sometimes, Miralyn asks her fellow farmers for strategies to keep the farm free of weeds and pests. She also sought the help of CEVI, a micro-finance institute in the Philippines, to help her finance her farm. She requested a loan of Php 6,000 which she will use to buy farm supplies like fertilizer. Hopefully, this loan will help her achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like fertilizer

loans.name: Evelina

texts.en:
Mrs. Evelina R. is a married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She is 42 years old and has two children.

Evelina is involved in rice farming. She shared that she only started with a small parcel of land and it grew to a bigger one due to hard work. She wants to expand more so that her income will also improve. The farm is the only source of income her family has so she and her husband make sure it is productive. Her children’s education is also one of her priorities so she has to set aside money for it.

Evelina recently joined CEVI and said that she joined because of its low interest rate. She would like to request a loan of Php 6,000 which she will use to buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies she lacks.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina D. S., 44,  has two children, with the oldest age 23. She is a farmer and she  also runs a small store, which, according to her, gives her a little daily income. Her main source of income is from her rice farm so she spends most of her time making sure it is free of weeds and pests. Like other farmers, Edwina aims to grow her farm to earn more income and to ease her family’s financial challenges.

Edwina has  applied to CEVI and requests for a loan of PHP6, 000. She said she would use the loan to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer and also crude oil for the tractor she uses at the farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: María Jesús

texts.es:
María Jesus es soltera, tiene 21 años de edad y vive junto a sus padres y sus hermanos menores en el sector El Romero del distrito de Mórrope, una zona rural ubicada a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Al igual que la mayoría de pobladores de la zona se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales. Ella cría pavos desde hace cuatro años y los vende a los negociantes que visitan la zona constantemente, este negocio le brinda los recursos necesarios para solventar sus gastos personales y apoyar a la economía del lugar, ya que su padre trabaja como agricultor y su madre confecciona alforjas y los que ambos perciben no es suficiente para mantener a la familia.

María Jesús desea mejorar la calidad de los animales que cría para poder venderlos a mejor precio, es por ello que se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Ella es una jovencita responsable y bastante trabajadora. Sus vecinos y conocidos le tienen mucha estima y cariño. En la imagen aparace junto a los pavos que está criando.
texts.en:
María Jesus, 21, is single and lives with her parents and younger siblings in the El Romero sector of Mórrope district; this is a rural area located an hour away from the city of Chiclayo. As most of the residents of this area, she raises small farm animals. She has raised turkeys for the last four years and sells them to merchants who constantly visit the area. This business provides her with the necessary resources to meet her personal expenses and to help out with the family economy because, although her father works as a farmer and her mother makes knapsacks, what they earn together is still insufficient to support the family. María Jesús hopes to improve the quality of the animals she raises to that she can sell them for a better price. For this reason, she is asking Edpyme Alternativa for her first, 1000 new sol, loan to help her meet this objective. She is a responsible and very hard-working young lady. Her neighbors and acquaintances hold her in high regard. In the photo, she appears with the turkeys she is raising.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy nutritionally balanced turkey feed.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana B. started farming in 2003. It has been her family’s source of income ever since. With eight children, she and her husband double their effort to make the most out of the farm. Ana is also starting to venture into another type of business,  hog raising, to better improve her income. She works hard to provide her family food to eat, clothes to wear and to give her children a proper education.

Ana is a new member of CEVI. She is applying for a loan of PHP6, 000. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies like fertilizer and hopefully will have enough left to buy piglets to start her hog raising business.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Niru

texts.en: Niru B. lives with her husband and two children. Her husband works in private office. She has two sons. Her older son is studying in grade 9 and younger son is studying in grade 4. Niru is engaged in selling cow's milk. She carries her milk containers and sells door to door daily in the morning and in the evening. She lives in Bhakepati and in that area the demand for milk is constantly increasing. In Nepal pure and fresh cow’s milk is highly valued for human nutrition. Niru  already owns one cow but because of the rising demand for milk, she wants to buy another cow to increase her production. She plans to use her loan to purchase a jersey cow which produces more milk than normal cows.

loans.use: To buy a jersey cow

loans.name: Fatouma

texts.en: Fatouma K. is 29 years old. She has three children and her husband works in the military. Mrs. K. works in the Grand Marché de Hedzranawoé selling snacks and staple food products. She began this business in 2005 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. Fatouma will use the majority of this loan to purchase cookies for resale and the remainder will go towards spaghetti and any other products she needs to keep her customers satisfied.

loans.use: To purchase of cookies, spaghetti and other food items for resale

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Laxmi S. lives in Sanepa. She has four members including herself in her family. Her husband is a taxi driver. They have one son and one daughter. Both her children are studying in primary school.
Laxmi  opened her butcher shop 1 year ago. She sells chicken and buff meat in her shop. She opened the butcher shop to improve the living standard of her family. Her husband also helps her in her work. Laxmi is requesting a loan of NPR15000 to buy a freezer to store meat.

loans.use: To buy a freezer to store meat

loans.name: Sesenio Jr.

texts.en:
Sesenio S. Jr. owns a sari-sari (convenience) store and at the same time a chain saw business in Talibon Bohol. He is a graduate loan recipient of Community Economic Ventures Inc.and that is why he qualifies for an ASENSO business loan which is intended for a client who has an established business. 

Sesehio would like to apply a loan of PHP 50,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for his business to offer her customers a wider selection.

CEVI supports its clients during the early stages of their business. It continues to support its clients during the later stage because it believes that the business will create a lot of employment for many people in the community.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for his sari-sari store

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en: Elsa R. has five children with her husband Aniceto. Both of them work hard to supply the needs of their household. Elsa is thankful for her farm because aside from getting income from it, she also doesn’t need to buy rice for her family to eat. She said that it lessens their expenses. Elsa is now preparing her farm for planting. She needs farm supplies so she has applied for a loan of PHP6,000 from CEVI. With this amount, Elsa will be able to buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies that she needs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Delia

texts.en: 50-year-old Delia A. is a married woman with eight children. Her oldest, who is now 32, lives outside the family home. Delia started farming in 2004 and says that her rice farm has really helped her family. It puts  food on the table and gives them clothes to wear. She hopes to make her rice farm grow so she would earn a better income.   Delia  joined CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines, to gain financial support and hopefully expand her business knowledge and opportunities. She has requested to loan of PHP6, 000, which, if granted, she would use to buy farm supplies like quality seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Harrison

texts.en:
Harrison V. is a businessman who sells general goods such as soft drinks, hairstyling kits, toothpaste, body cream, beverages, and children's clothing.  He buys his goods wholesale from the Red Light Market on the outskirts of Liberia's capital Monrovia and sells from a retail shop in the Kpelle Town community of nearby Paynesville.

Harrison is 28 years old and is married with a 7 year-old-child who is attending kindergarten.  Harrison himself is a high school graduate.  He is preparing to go to college because he is seeking a higher education.

Harrison has been running his business for 5 years and hopes to grow his business into a larger store in the near future.  He started selling on a table in front of his house, and then moved into a little booth.  His business has now grown into a small shop.

Harrison credits his success in business to maintaining good relationships with residents of Kpelle Town in Paynesville, his customers.  He needs this loan in order purchase more hairstyling kits, tooth paste, body cream, tissue, and other goods.  He plans to invest any extra money into his cement and call center businesses.

Harrison dreams of becoming more successful in the future, and hopes to educate his son well.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more more products such as hairstyling kits, toothpaste, body cream, tissue, clothing, and beverages.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en: Maricel V. has been involved in rice farming for 10 years. She is thankful for this business because it helps her family’s finances to be sustained. She also wants her four children to be given a proper education so she works hard. Maricel needs additional capital to fund her farm. She heard of CEVI from fellow farmers and immediately joined when it opened in her area. Maricel has requested for a loan of PHP6, 000. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies that she needs for her rice farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Compile

texts.en: Compile S. used to borrow money from lenders who charge high interest. She said she barely earned  any money because of it. Still, she works hard at her rice farm to help provide for her family’s needs. She and her husband exert extra effort to sustain their children's education. When she heard of CEVI and the low interest rate it offers, she immediately joined the MFI. She has requested a loan of PHP6, 000, which she would use to acquire fertilizer and other necessary farm supplies she needs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Juana María

texts.es:
Juana tiene 66 años de edad, es viuda, tiene 5 hijos ya independizados y vive sola en el sector La Ladrillera del distrito de Cayaltí, ubicado a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Tiene instalada en su vivienda una pequeña bodega desde hace seis años. Ella nos comenta que logró instalarla con los ahorros de su actividad por venta de animales, en su negocio ella ofrece productos de primera necesidad (arroz, azúcar. Aceite), abarrotes y bebidas a sus vecinos, adicionalmente vende comida en el mercado de la ciudad los dias martes.

Este negocio es de mucha utilidad para los vecinos de la zona, ya que les provee de articulos de uso diario por los que tendrían que recorrer una distancia larga debido a que el lugar queda alejado del centro del distrito.

Juana desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más productos de primera necesidad y abarrotes, por ello se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.

Ella es una mujer bastante trabajadora y que se lleva bien con sus vecinos, los cuales siempre recurren a ella cuando necesitan de ayuda.
texts.en:
Juana is a 66 year old widow. She has five independent children, and she lives alone in the La Ladrillera sector of the Cayaltí district. It is one hour from the city of Chiclayo. She has had a small convenience store set up in her home for six years. She tells us that she was able to set it up with the savings from her activity of selling animals. In her business she sells basic needs products (rice, sugar, oil), groceries, and drinks to her neighbors. She also sells food in the city market on Tuesdays. This business is very useful to the neighbors in the area because it provides them with articles for daily use. They would have to travel a long distance because the place is far from the center of the district. Juana wishes to expand her business and buy more basic needs products and groceries. That is why she has seen the need to request, for the first time, a loan from Edpyme Alternativa for 500 PEN. She is a very hard-working woman who gets along well with her neighbors. They always come to her when they need help.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic needs products and groceries to expand her business

loans.name: Angélica Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora está solicitando un crédito con CEPRODEL para la compra de artículos escolares y uniformes, ella es madre soltera, tiene dos hijos en edad escolar a los que ella les quiere brindar todo su apoyo para que tengan un futuro mejor. Ella trabaja de secretaria en la Alcaldía de Nindirí con este salario  ella provee el sustento  y una vida digna a sus menores hijos.
texts.en:
She is requesting a credit with Ceprodel for the purchase of school supplies and uniformes. She is a single mother, and has two school-aged children to whom she wants to give all her support so that they can have a better life. She works as a secretary in the Nindirí town hall, and with this salary she gives sustenance and a life of dignity to her young children.

Translated from Spanish by Amy Schapiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of school supplies and uniforms

loans.name: Nurra

texts.en: Mrs. Nurra P., 35, is a tailor in the village of Khokhana-Dobato. She has one son and one daughter. Her daughter is studying in grade 2 and her son is studying in grade 7. Both Nurra P. and her husband, Surendra P., make different types of dresses for both ladies and gentlemen. Tailoring is their traditional work. Mrs. P. plans to use the loan of Rs 20000.00 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to use her income for self improvement and for her children's education. In Nepal the cost of a good education is increasing and Mrs. P. is saving her income to provide a good education for her children.

loans.use: To buys raw materials for her tailoring work

loans.name: Leonita

texts.en: At 61, Leonita R. still wants to be active in her business. She is a  rice farmer. She is married and has an only child who is now 27 years old. Leonita  has been farming since 1980 and continues to do so because it provides income for her family. She recently joined CEVI to expand her business opportunities. Leonita is asking for a loan PHP6,000. The loan will be used for farm supplies like seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Afia

texts.en: Afia B. lives in the town of Abura, where she makes a living selling yams. She has received a junior high education, is married and has one child. Her husband makes a living selling spare parts for cars. In addition to her own work, she helps her husband with his and runs their home. She has applied for a loan to buy more yams to sell. Afia hopes to use the new profits made possible by this loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more yams to sell.

loans.name: Gilma

texts.es:
LA SEÑORITA GILMA G., TINE 30 AÑOS Y VIVE EN LA LOCALIDADA DE MIZQUE QUE ESTA A 4 HORAS DE LA CIUDAD DE COCHABAMBA, UN PUEBLO PEQUEÑO DONDE LA ACTIVIDAD PRINCIPAL ES LA AGRICULTURA, Y GANADERIA.

GILMA TRABAJA LA TIERRA Y TAMBIEN SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE LECHE EN EL PUEBLO, ELLA ACTUALMENTE ESTA 
HACIENDO UNA MAESTRIA EN ADMINISTRACION DE EMPRESAS, QUIERE EJERCER SU CARRERA LO MAS ANTES POSIBLE PARAA SI PODER TERMINAR DE CONSTRUIR LA CASITA QUE TIENE JUNTO  A SU MAMA Y SU PAPA.LA SEÑORITA GILMA TAMBIEN A SIDO POSTULADA POR UN FRENTE POLITICO PARA OPTAR POR EL CARGO DE CONSEJAL DE MIZQUE, TENIENDO MUCHA OPORTUNIDAD DE GANAR POR LA SIMPATIA Y CARIÑO QUE LE TIENEN, YA QUE SABEN QUE ES UNA PERSONA MUY TRABAJADORA Y QUERENDONA DE SU FAMILIA Y SU PUEBLO.

LA SEÑORITA GILMA SOLICITO EL CREDITO PARA PODER SALIR ADELANTE JUNTO A  SU GANADO Y TIERRA, YA QUE QUIERE CRECER MAS COMO AGRICULTORA Y GANADERA, EL SUEÑO QUE TIENE ELLA ES EL QUE A SU FAMILIA NO LE FALTE NADA, TERMINAR SU MAESTRIA Y QUE SUS TIERRAS SEAN LAS MEJORES DE LA ZONA.
texts.en:
Senorita Gilma G. is 30 years old and lives in the town of Mizque, four hours from the city of Cochabamba, it is a small town where the principal activity is agriculture and livestock. Gilma works the land and also sells milk in the town, she is actually working on a Masters in Business Administration. She wants to practice her career as soon as possible so that she is able to finish building the house that she has with her mother and father. Gilma has also been nominated by a political group for office on the Council of Mizque. She has a good opportunity to win due to the kindness and affection that she has, people know that she is a very hard working person and she is loved by her family and town. Gilma is seeking a loan to be able to get ahead with her cattle and land, she already wants to grow more as a farmer. The dream that she has is that her family doesn't lack anything, to finish her MBA and that her land is the best in the area.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food for dairy cows

loans.name: Jyanti

texts.en: Jyanti K. has two sons who attend middle and high school. She lives in a joint family with her father-in-law and mother-in-law. Jayanti already owns one cow, and she has been selling milk in the area. In Nepal, pure, fresh cow’s milk is highly valued for its nutrition. Jyanti lives in a growing neighborhood, and in that area the demand for milk is constantly increasing. She carries her milk containers and sells door to door daily, in the morning and evening. Because of the rising demand, Jyanti wants to buy another cow to increase  milk production. She is requesting a loan of NPR25,000 to purchase a jersey cow, which produces more milk than normal cows. Jyanti has grassland of her own, so she does not have to buy food for her cows.

loans.use: To buy a jersey cow

loans.name: Mana

texts.en:
Mana sells live goats in Benin City to make a living. He has been in this business for some years. One of his challenges is the long distances he travels in his business. He hopes to increase his business capital to enable him to purchase more goats and avoid so much traveling. Mana is a client of LAPO Microfinance and has a good repayment record. He hopes for a loan of NGN150, 000 to purchase more goats to sell. 

Mana is married with seven children between the ages of four and 22. With the proceeds from the business he could take care of his family and his children’s education. He says he is grateful to all Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more goats to sell.

loans.name: Anita Del Carmen

texts.es:
Anita tiene 20 años de edad, es soltera y vive junto a su padre, sus hermanos y su madrastra en el distrito de Nueva Arica, un distrito de la zona rural ubicado a hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Anita se dedica a apoyar a su padre en el negocio de la panaderia, hace algunos meses su padre le dio la facilidad de tener sus propios clientes y ella ha empezado a trabajar elaborando pan y distribuyéndolo en las bodegas de Nueva Arica y sus caseríos. El negocio le ha ido muy bien y ahora se esfuerza a diario para seguir adelante.

La labor de Anita empieza desde muy temprano, las cuatro de la mañana, a esa hora ayuda a su padre a hornear el pan y a partir de las sesis empieza a distribuirlo, la masa es preparada en la noche anterior. Anita desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más insumos para seguir elaborando pan, por ello se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.

Anita es una joven trabajadora y muy empeñosa en el trabajo que hace. Su sueño es poder implementar una bodega con los ahorros de su actual actividad. En la imagen aparece junto a su padre.
texts.en:
Anita is 20 years old, she is single and lives with her father, her brothers and her step mother in the district of Nueva Arica, a district in the rural zone located an hour and a half from the city of Chiclayo. Anita supports her father in the bread making business, some months ago her father let her take on her own clients. She has begun making bread and distributing it to the stores of Nueva Arica and the nearby areas. The business has done very well and now she strives daily to keep going. Anita's work begins very early, at four in the morning, at this hour she helps her father to bake the bread and, at six to split the distribution. The dough is prepared the night before. Anita wishes to increase her business with the purchase of more ingredients to continue making bread, this is why she is asking for a loan for the first time from Edpyme Alternativa a loan of 1500 Nuevos Soles. Anita is young, hardworking and earnest. Her dream is to be able to start a store with the savings of her business, she imagines it with her father.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for the making of bread

loans.name: Anesita

texts.en: Anesita O., 33, owns a sari-sari (convenience) store. She sells various types of goods in her store to provide for the daily needs around her neighborhood. She started this business in 2005. Now she’s a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and is requesting a loan of 8,000PHP, enough to provide additional capital to fill her store with groceries. Anesita works hard to provide for her family's daily needs and this loan will help her do that.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her convenience store

loans.name: Osato

texts.en:
Osato is a 35 years old, married with two children in school. He sells cows in one of the cattle markets in Benin City. He has been in this business with success for 15 years. His business has been much improved due to the extra capital he got from LAPO Microfinance. Osato pays back his loans on time. He wants to expand the size of his business by buying more cows to sell. 

He is requesting another loan of NGN150,000 to purchase more cows to sell. He says thanks for the support.

loans.use: To purchase more cows to sells.

loans.name: Abla

texts.en: Abla A. is married to a carpenter and has 2 children. She lives and works in the Hédranawoé district of Lomé, Togo selling palm oil, onions, a milled flour called “gari” made from manioc, and a local alcoholic beverage called Sodabi. She began this business in 2007 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. Abla will use these funds to resupply her stock and cover the costs of transport to various markets around the city where she purchases her supply. This loan will help Mrs.A. support her family and allow her business to flourish.

loans.use: To resupply stocks of palm oil, onions, milled manioc flour, and a local beverage

loans.name: Irina

texts.en: Irina G. is single. She runs a footwear sales business in one of the local markets in her home town of Zaporozhye. She sells shoes, boots and sock liners. Irina owns a nice spacious vending kiosk. She opened it 3 years ago. Presently, Irina has 17,000 UAH invested in inventory. Her monthly income amounts to 7,000 UAH. Irina is seeking to expand her business. She is hoping to use this loan of 5,500 UAH to finish re-construction of her second vending facility and stock it with merchandise. Irina is a determined person. She always seeks to achieve her goals and works hard to succeed.

loans.use: To finish reconstruction of a second shop and to stock it with merchandise

loans.name: Big Five Marketer Group

texts.en:
Big Five Marketer is a group of 5 borrowers led by Daniel S.. He is 48 years old and is married with a big family.  Daniel is a high school graduate but could not continue with school due to a lack of financial support.

For more than 10 years, Daniel has been selling general goods and palm oil at the Joe Bar Market near Liberia's capital Monrovia. Daniel encourages customers to buy from him by selling high quality goods and palm oil. Daniel will use this loan to purchase more palm oil.  He dreams of giving his children a good future by sending them to school and building a house for his family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Daniel is the one holding the sign.  Mamie P. is inset at the lower right of the photo.   This is the second time that Daniel's group has been listed on Kiva -- see the first listing here: http://www.kiva.org/lend/141616. 

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil.

loans.name: Grupo "el Regalo De Dios" Group

texts.en: These people that currently live in the Candelaria sector of the village Nahualata, San Antonio Suchitepéquez, are very responsible, since in the community where they live, they collaborate for each activity done. They also have their small businesses in the community, which are to benefit and meet the needs of the community residents. They have the support of their husbands who work on different cane cutting farms, but their earnings are not sufficient for basic needs such as the education of their children. As a result, they work very hard with their businesses to be able to obtain an acceptable education. Four members sell food outsiD. local schools and one sells clothes. This is why they thought it necessary to go to the association’s office to apply for a loan to meet their needs. [[[Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer]]]

loans.use: To purchase food, clothing and raw materials for making tortillas (corn) to sell in their businesses.

loans.name: Mery

texts.en: Mery F. has been a second-hand clothes seller in Abura for some time. Her education is junior high level. Mery is married and has two children. Her husband also sells second hand clothes. She supports her husband in the general upkeep of the house. Her loan will be used to buy more second-hand clothes for sale. She hopes to use the increased profits to reinvest into her business.

loans.use: To buy more secondhand clothes for sale.

loans.name: Isabel Cristina

texts.es:
Isabel es una madre de familia de 50 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a su menor hija en el distrito de Cayaltí, ubicado a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza por catálogo desde hace más de cinco años, ella nos cuenta que empezó en esta actividad porque le gusta siempre mantenerse activa y porque así puede apoyar a la economía de su familia. Isabel siempre se encuentra buscando nuevos clientes y ahora es muy conocida en la zona.

Isabel desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más productos de belleza con los cuales pueda tener un stock permanente que ofrecer a sus clientes. Por ello ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Isabel es conocida por su buen carácter y su honradez. Esta es la segunda vez que trabaja con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado ser una cliente puntual y responsable.
texts.en:
Isabel is a mother of 50 years old. She lives with her husband and their youngest daughter in the district of Cayaltí, located one hour from the city of Chiclayo. She sells beauty products and has for more than five years. She told us that she began with this activity because she likes to always be active and because in this way she can support her family economically. Isabel is always finding new clients and is well known in the area. Isabel wishes to increase her business with the purchase of more beauty products with which she can keep as a permanent stock to offer to her clients. This is why she is seeking from Edpyme Alternativa a loan of 1000 Nuevos Soles that will help her to achieve her objective. Isabel is known for her good character and her honesty. This is the second time that she has worked with Edpyme Alternative and has demonstrated herself to be a punctual and responsible client.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products to increase her businbess

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.en: Akossiwa A. is married to a motorcycle taxi driver and they have no children. Akossiwa runs a restaurant serving a wide range of customers in her neighborhood. Her restaurant employs 3 employees who all work hard keeping Mrs. A.’s customers satisfied. She began this business in 2005 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. She will use these funds to purchase yams, corn, and condiments for the  preparation of her meals. She will also purchase beverages for her customers to drink. This loan will help Mrs. A. will keep her customers and her family happy and well fed.

loans.use: To purchase of yams, corn, condiments, and beverages

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
