Mrs. Same V. (in the photo), 53, and her husband, Mr. Beun Brak, 54, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 km from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1980 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Two of the children are married and live in separate homes. The other two children work in a garment factory. One of them is disabled.  

Same has been a silk weaver since she was 16 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a farmer. 

Same is requesting her first loan of $150 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Vang

texts.en: Vang B., age 57, is widowed and resides with her son in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. For 13 years, Vang has been engaged in the business of producing traditional baskets, earning an income of U.S. $5 per day which enables her to cover her family expenses. Her son is employed as a construction worker, earning U.S. $3 per day. Vang is now requesting a loan of U.S. $600 to purchase rubber for resale to people who produce the traditional baskets. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, partnered Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase rubber for resale

loans.name: Coceta

texts.en:
Coceta Y., currently in the business of selling rice in a shop, is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of rice and posho to sell. Coceta is 40 years old and married to a policeman. She has four children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of rice and posho to sell

loans.name: Sophon

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophon M., 31, and her husband, Mr. Sokhom Phat, 24, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2008 and just have a young son.

Sophon has been a silk weaver since she was 16 years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a construction worker.

Sophon is requesting a loan of $250 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Tajihan Jeenkulova`s Group

texts.en: Tajihan is 53 years old and is married with one son, a pupil. Her husband works as a yardman in the local school. Tajihan’s main business is livestock. She fattens them at home in autumn-winter and goes to pasture in spring-summer. She started her business with just two cows and now she looks after fifty cattle. This loan will be used to buy fodder and hay. Besides meat, she also sells milk products. Her average income per month is about 150 USD. Our next borrower is Kanayim. She is 44 years old and the mother of two daughters, both pupils. Her husband is a builder, usually working in Uzgen district. Kanayim keeps some animals. Either she looks after them at home or sends them to pasture because the cost of keeping them is less there. Her loan will be used to buy two calves. Gulzina is 25 years old. Her husband is in Moscow and is working as a builder there. With her husband’s family she is involved in farming. They raise corn and sunflowers. Sunflower seeds are then used to produce vegetable oil. Her loan will be used to cover sowing costs in the upcoming spring. Temirlan is 24 years old and is the youngest member of this group. His wife is a housewife raising their little daughter. Like the other members of this group, Temirlan fattens animals. Usually it is the only source of income in rural areas. His loan will be used to buy two calves. In the future he hopes to build his own house for his growing family. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy fodder and hay for her cattle

loans.name: Tsetsegdulam

texts.en:
Tsetsegdulam is 30 years old and lives with her son in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own apartment. Her husband was in a mining accident and receives a disability pension.

Tsetsegdulam has been operating her wholesale Mongolian products business for four years. Recently, domestically produced Mongolian products have become rarer, and she has been selling only underwear and scarfs made in Mongolia.

Tsetsegdulam is a very hardworking person. She says, “I'm spending a lot of time and money for my husband's treatment because it's so important to us, and I would like to see my husband recovered.”

Tsetsegdulam is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan to increase her inventory of scarfs, socks, and underwear.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies for her business

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Chum S., age 42, is married and resides with her two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She operates a business as a recycler and is also a farmer, earning an income of US$2.80 per day.

S.’s husband is employed to transport fish to the market, earning an income of US$3 per day. By doing so, he is able to cover the family expenses, especially the children’s education. He has been with this job since 2008.

S. is requesting a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike with a trailer attached to expand her husband’s business of transporting fish for his customers. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike with a trailer attached for her husband's business

loans.name: Rum

texts.en: Mrs. S. is a 47 years old and a resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She earns a living as a garment worker, getting a specific salary of over a hundred dollars a month. S. has a life partner in her husband, who helps support the family by working as a local chef. The couple was married many years ago and has two children. One of them is married and other one is single and a security guard. S. will be using her first loan to mend and improve her house, which is too old and breaking down. (Mrs. S.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To mend and improve her old house

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
As a way to achieve her dreams for her family, a hardworking mother, Imelda I., wants to grow her fishing business in partnership with her husband. To do that she is requesting a much larger loan from Kiva through ASHI to purchase the necessary materials for building a small fishing boat.

Once they have a boat of their own to be managed by her husband, Imelda can sell more fish and more often because they will be in control of their business unlike when her husband only borrows the fishing boat of their neighbor.

To be able to cope up the daily expenses that her family incurs, aside from selling fish, Imelda works in a farm as a hired laborer. However, income is just small despite of the whole day of hard work.With that,the growth of her fishing and fish selling business is very important for her and her family because her aspiration of improving the standard of living of her family depends on its profits. Hence, she is very much hopeful that lenders all over the world through Kiva and through ASHI will extend generosity to her and her family.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials for building a small fishing boat

loans.name: Larm

texts.en:
Larm N. is a farmer, earning US $2 per day. She is 42 years old, married and lives with her four children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Her husband is a farmer too, and he earns the same income as his wife. The family is also assisted by N.’s two, who are currently employed at a local garment factory in the province. 

N. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase a horse and a cart for her husband to operate a business transporting goods for people in their village. This is N.’s first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a cart and horse

loans.name: Khen

texts.en:
Khen S. H. works as a farmer, earning US $2 per day. She is 33 years old, married and lives with her six-year-old child in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Her husband operates a cart and horse to provide transportation service to people in their village, earning US $7 per day. By doing so, he is able to cover the family's expenses, especially the children’s education. He has been with this job since 2001. 

H. is requesting a loan of US $1200 to purchase a plot of farmland to expand into agricultural products. This is her second loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: E. Mary is 36 years old and lives with her husband in the Phnom Penh province. Since 2008, she has been selling fish in the local market to earn a living and is able to make about US$2 per day. Her husband is a recycler and sometime he takes his time to operate a moto-taxi business. On average, he makes US$2 a day. E. Mary is asking for a loan of US$500 to reinvest in her fish business and the rest is use to expand her husband’s recycling business.

loans.use: Sell fish.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen A. is currently in the business of selling various items in a retail shop and is requesting a loan to stock bags of sugar and rice to sell.  Hellen is 39 years old and is married with a husband that is a doctor. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock bags of sugar and rice to sell.

loans.name: Mi

texts.en:
Mr. Mi T., age 64 year-old and his wife, Mrs. Eun I (pictured together), age 58 year-old, live on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1974 and have three children: two daughters married and live in separated home and son has full-time employment.  

Mi is a farmer, he grows corn and banana. His wife has been a silk weaver since she was 15 years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market.  

Mi is requesting a loan of $400 to pay school fee for his son-in-law who is learning electronic skill.

loans.use: To pay school fee for his son-in-law who is learning electronic skill.

loans.name: Idermunh

texts.en:
Idermunh is 29 years old and lives with his parents and two younger siblings in Tuv province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. His father works at a government tax office, and his mother works as a accountant for an electric power center. They have been living in their current home for 19 years. They repaired their car this year with money from these jobs. 

Idermunh has been operating a taxi service since 2008. After running his business for almost three years, he has a number of consistent customers. Idermunh's customers usually call him by phone when they need his services, an arrangement convenient for the customers. His average daily revenue is approximately 15,000 tugrugs (~ 10 USD). Previously, he had a Korean “Excel” car, but he was able to acquire the higher quality Toyota Chaser for his taxi service. 

Furthermore, since 2008 Idermunh has been growing potatoes in Jargalan soum of Tov province as well. He is a decent and very hardworking person. He says, “I would like to work hard in order to expand the business and to purchase my own place to live separately from the family. ” He is requesting a 3,600,000 tugrug loan to purchase large amount of seed  potato to plant in the upcoming spring.

loans.use: To purchase large amount of potato seeds to plant

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Pich S., age 38, is married and resides with her children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is has a business selling soup in her village, earning a gross income of US$ 14 per day. Her husband operates a business of producing rice wine at home, earning an income of US$ 7 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially on the children’s education. She has been with this job since 2004. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more various kinds of beverage to stock her food store. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: buy beverage to stock the store

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann C. is a quiet type of person. She is a 39-year-old mother and has three children whose ages range from five to 11 years old. With the support of her husband, she joined ASHI and has requested for a loan to start up her own business. Since their town is far and is less accessible to transportation, public market and other services, Mary Ann plans to retail gasoline in their own small house. 

Potential costumers of her business are the tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar/Filipino version of rickshaw) and motorcycle drivers.  The proceeds of this business will be her source to ease the struggle of her husband in providing them money for their needs everyday especially of their children. Mary Ann really hopes that someday her business would grow wherein she can afford the franchise of a gasoline station for a stable economy and to be able to graduate her children from college.

loans.use: To purchase gasoline for retail.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more soda crates for her business.

loans.name: Ngi

texts.en: Ngi S., age 37, is married and resides with her children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has two children. She has a business of selling various kinds of groceries at home, earning an income of US$ 5 per day. Her husband operates a business of selling palm juice and fruits, earning an income of US$ 5 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially on the children’s education. She has been with this job since 1990. S. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase more various kinds of groceries to stock the store. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered Kiva.

loans.use: buy groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Savorn

texts.en: S. Savorn is 53 years old and lives with her husband in the Kampong Chhnang province. Since 1990, she has been selling fish in the local market to earn a living and is able to make about US$5 of profit a day. Her husband stays at home and sometimes he also help her selling fish. This couple has five children, two whom are in school and three are employed with different jobs. S. Savorn is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike so that she can use it to transport fish to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Gene

texts.en:
Gene C. joined ASHI recently to request for a loan which will enable her to grow her small “sari-sari” (variety) store business. Her family - including her three children ages 7 to 10 years - is ble to enjoy the profit of her business.  However, she has been unable to grow the business quickly due to lack of capital. In this case, Gene now is requesting for a loan from ASHI. Hopefully she will be able to increase the inventory of her store and will gain more customers.

Gene dreams of graduating her children from college in the future. Therefore, she wants to support them in all of their needs for the enhancement of their growth as a person and as human beings through the proceeds of her business.

loans.use: To purchase goods to sell in her store.

loans.name: Abau

texts.en:
Abau E. sells bread at the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bread for sale. Abau is 30 years old and is married to a a businessman. She has 3 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bakery.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to purchase more bread to sell.

loans.name: Tharch

texts.en: Tharch S., 31, is married and lives with her children in Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has three children. She sells groceries and traditional baskets, earning an income of US$7.50 per day. Her husband is a construction worker and is able to earn an income of US$7.60 per day. S. is requesting a loan of US$700 to purchase more baskets for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more baskets for resale

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarom S. (shown in the photo) is 24 and her husband, Mr. Onn Ngoun, is 30. They have been married since 1994 and have two children: one son and one daughter who both go to school. The family lives along National Road Number Six, about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.


Sarom has been raising pigs for two years, while her husband has been a fisherman for seven years. She hopes to expand her business. Therefore, she is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase additional piglets to raise and food for pigs.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and food for pigs.

loans.name: Im

texts.en: P. Im, 62, buys and sells rice in the local market in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a widow with three children. One works in security while the others are garment factory workers. She typically makes about US$3 each day. She would like a loan to purchase rice from individual growers to resell to the market wholesaler. To increase her profits she is asking for US$800 to purchase more rice to sell in the market.

loans.use: to buy rice for resale

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en: Yeng L., 39, is married and lives with her children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has two children. She sells traditional baskets, earning an income of US$4.30 per day. Her husband operates a business as a construction foreman, earning a gross income of US$20 per day. By doing so, he is able to cover his family expenses, particularly his children’s education. He has been doing this job since 2002. L. is requesting a loan of US$700 to purchase more baskets for resale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more baskets for resale

loans.name: Tsendsuren

texts.en:
Tsendsuren has operated a clothing retail business since 1997. She is 72 years old and lives with her daughter in Tuv province, Mongolia. She and her daughter have lived together, in their own apartment, for 35 years. Tsendsuren's daughter supports the business, and they have been able to repair their home and furniture with their earnings. Additionally, Tsendsuren pays for her grandchildren's university tuition fees every year. 

Originally, Tsendsuren's working capital was 100,000 tugrugs (~$70 US). But now her working capital has increased to 3,500,000 tugrugs (~$2,463 US) through her hard work and determination. She has much business experience gained in previous years. Tsendsuren operates her business year-round, any she has a large and increasing number of regular customers. Tsendsuren is a decent and very hardworking person. She says, “I'm working hard in order to expand my business and to create my own shop.” 

Tsendsuren is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more inventory for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fish in bulk

loans.name: Eoun

texts.en: Eoun P., age 41, is married and resides with her children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is involved in a business selling fruit at a local market in the province, earning a gross income of US $15 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family's expenses, especially those of the children’s education. She has been doing this job since 2007. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of US $1 per day. Eoun P. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase more mangoes for resale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy mangoes for resale

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean G.'s loan will be used to start up an “auto-load” (prepaid loading of cellular phones) business. Since Mary Jean’s village is unreachable by a post paid telecommunication services, people are using prepaid mobile phones. Compared to post paid telecommunication networks, this fits the budget of poor people because loading can be controlled and used only when communication is necessary. Profit from this business is small; however, Mary Jean can patiently wait until it grows while maximizing her earnings for necessary expenses.

Mary Jean joined ASHI just recently, hoping that by having her own business for a source of income, everyday life will be easier despite their being poor. Her husband is a small-time laborer generating just a small amount of income. Financing to meet her family’s daily needs is very hard for Mary Jean; hence, she requests a loan from Kiva through ASHI, Kiva's field partner in the Philippines.

loans.use: To purchase prepaid cellular phone load for retail

loans.name: Joan

texts.en: Joan N. runs a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling food and daily use products in her community. She is 24 years old, married and has one young child. They are from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. Joan has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Joan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Joan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase products to sell. Joan is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Hoy

texts.en: Hoy H., age 31, is married and resides with her children in Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She has a business selling fish and vegetables at a local market in the province, earning an income of US $5 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family's expenses, especially those for her children’s education. She has been doing this job since 2001. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of US $2 per day. H. is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase more fish for resale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fish for resale

loans.name: Jein

texts.en:
Jein P. is currently in the business of selling clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more new and used clothes to sell. Jein is 45 years old and is married to a potter. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a beauty saloon.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Eam

texts.en: Eam S., age 42, is married and resides in Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia. She is a farmer, earning an income of US $2 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family's expenses. She has been doing this job since 1988. Her husband is a well digger, earning an income of approximately US $10 per day. S. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase more tools to dig wells to expand her husband's current business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy tools to dig wells

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen Z. is a 57-year-old hard working mother of eight children. Being a mother, her greatest achievement in life is graduating five of her children from college despite being poor. Now, only her three youngest children are living with her and her husband at home since her elder children have their own families. These three are still studying in high school and Helen wishes to support their education until college just like her elder children. Therefore, together with her husband, she decided to join ASHI and request a loan to finance the growth of their “muscovado” sugar production.

“Muscovado” sugar is an organic brown sugar made out of the sugar cane plant. Unlike the early years, the demand for this kind of sugar nowadays is higher because it is healthier and recommended even by doctors. Therefore, profits from this business could possibly increase. But they need a larger amount of capital to increase production and supply. For Helen to be able to comply with her business requirements and her children’s needs, she is requesting a loan from Kiva through ASHI. Her proceeds will go to the education of her children once they are in college and to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To finance the production of her muscovado sugar production.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, rice, beans, and rice flour.

loans.name: Morm

She runs a business selling used clothes at a local market in the province, earning an income of US$6 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially for the children’s education. She has been with this job since 2008. Her husband is an engineering soldier for the province, and he also produces jars for sale, earning an income of US$2 per day. L. is requesting a loan of US$700 to purchase a shop at the market to sell used clothes. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered by Kiva. (L. is pictured in front her husband business)

loans.use: To buy a shop at the market to sell used clothes

loans.name: Lerma

texts.en:
Lerma S. is from the village of Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 70 years old. Lerma is separated from her spouse and has seven adult children. To make a living, Lerma owns and operates a business in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Lerma has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lerma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lerma has successfully repaid a previous loan from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lerma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lerma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Sokla

texts.en: V. Sokla, 29, sells cosmetics products and also work as a hairdresser in the local market of her Kampong Chhnang province. She is married, with two children who are still living at home, and her husband works as a car driver. She typically makes about US$5 each day, and would like a loan to expand her business. In order to increase her profits, she is asking for US$600 to purchase more cosmetics to sell in the market.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics to sell in the market

loans.name: Mourn

texts.en: Mourn S., age 42, is married and resides with her children in Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has three children. She works in the agriculture sector as a farmer raising pigs and growing rice with her husband, earning an income of USD 5 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. The family is also assisted by one of the children who is a local primary school teacher, earning USD 2 per day. Sakhorn is requesting a loan of USD 750 to purchase a mill to grind rice. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered by Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a mill to grind rice

Linda is 35 years old and is married with a husband who is a potter. She has three children and they go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

loans.name: Som

texts.en:
S. is 49 years old and a mother to four children: one is married and lives separately and the others are single and under her care.

In the beginning of 2000, S. built a small store in front of her home. In her shop, she sells a few types of cooking ingredients to the neighbors who live near her house in the village. To help feed the family, her husband earns a living as a security guard for a company.

S. is a hardworking woman who tries to earn money in order to send all her kids to the university. She needs a Kiva loan to increase the inventory of her store.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of her store

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling video compact disc (VCD's) in the local community. Aliyyah has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Aliyyah joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aliyyah has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Aliyyah is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be the secondloan taken out by Aliyyah from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Ngen

texts.en: Ngen S., age 39, is widowed and resides with her children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has a 15-year-old child. She is ina business of selling Cambodian traditional cakes and rents part of her land to a mobile company to install satellite, earning an income of $5 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially her child’s education. She has been with this job since 2005. S. is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a plot of farmland to expand the agricultural products. This is her third loan from CREDIT, partnered Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace S. has six children to nurture and look after until they are fully grown and independent from her. At their current ages, which range from 2 to 18 years old, everything they need depends on Grace and her husband’s income. Because of the very poor condition of Grace and her husband’s economy, their two eldest children have stopped schooling. Grace, however, is sad about this and is scared that the rest of their children would end up in high school and not in college. She is worried that her children will walk through the same pattern of life as hers. To keep her children away from the kind of life she had and is still having now, she joined ASHI and is requesting for a loan to start a hog-fattening business. The hogs/pigs she will fatten in four months will be sold either alive or slaughtered thereafter. The profit on this kind of business is much bigger once the volume of hogs fattened and sold is added together.

loans.use: To purchase hogs/pigs for fattening and selling

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie T. is a bona fide resident of Butuay Jimenez Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Melanie is married and has two children who are now adult-aged. To make a living, Melanie owns and operates a manufacturing venture. Melanie has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Melanie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melanie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from PMPC. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the second taken out by Melanie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: For additional capital for her business

She is in a business of buying more rice in stock to resell to make more profit, earning an income of  $7 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. Her husband helps his wife in the business, earning an income of $6 per day. He has been with this job since 2000. K. is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase more rice from the local farmer in stock. This is her second loan from CREDIT, partnered Kiva. loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn M. is a single parent who solely bears the challenges of raising and supporting the needs of her only child Rojene. Though she and Rojene lives together with her parents, she doesn’t like to depend on them for their own needs, especially for her child’s. Therefore, when she heard about ASHI in their village, she joined this group of four women who have common dream in life - to live out of poverty.

After everyone in the group she joined in ASHI was recognized as an official member, she requested a loan which she will use to start up a business that she will grow some day. Arlyn plans to purchase a pig for fattening and sell it either alive or slaughtered after four months of raising. Through her profits she hopes to someday make her life stable so that she can live independently of her parents.

loans.use: To purchase a pig for fattening and selling.

She is supported by her husband who catches fish and sells them at the local market. On average, he makes US $4.00 each day. T. Kamsot would like a loan of $400 to purchase fertilizer for her farm.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients in bulk for her cafe.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth G. is a cheerful mother of four children whose ages range from one to 12 years old. She joined ASHI just recently because she wants to fulfill her dream of supporting the education of her children until they graduate from college. The loan she is requesting from Kiva through its partner organization in the Philippines, ASHI, will be used to purchase dried fish to sell. 

Dried fish is the most common way to preserve fish, especially during harvest season where the supply is huge and the demand is low. Therefore, it is sold at a cheaper cost. When fish is out of season, the price gets high and people tend to buy dried fish instead. This is actually common for the whole Antique province and products are even sold in huge malls in different cities in different regions. 

For Elizabeth, the proceeds of her business will be used to finance the basic needs of her children. She hopes that her business someday will grow and become a source for the education of her children when they are in college.

loans.use: To puchase dried fish to sell

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok K., age 28, is married and resides with her children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has three children. She is a farmer who grows rice with her husband, earning an income of US $2.70 each per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially those for the children’s education. She has been doing this job since 2000. K. is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase more bananas and mangoes to sell to make more profit for the family. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.name: Feliza

texts.en:
A resident of Bolinsong, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental is our featured entrepreneur. She is Mrs. Feliza H., 39 years of age and married to Eddie H. who is a fisherman. They were blessed with 10 children. Two of the children are now working, three are school age and five are still infants. Her daughter is with her in the picture. The couple felt some hardships, especially in raising their 10 children. To help her husband, she decided to engage in business and opened up a sari-sari store in her house. For 10 years, she has been able to sustain the business. At this time she is earning an average net income of not less than P2,500 a month. This amount is so beneficial to their family, especially in meeting their daily needs. She undoubtedly joined the cooperative in 2010. As a newly recognized member, she is given the privilege to borrow P5,000 to add to her capital for her existing sari-sari store business. The future income from this loan will be used for their daily needs, tuition fees, loan repayments and savings for future use. She is hoping that someday all her children can graduate from college with the help of this business.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Margery

texts.en:
A 25-year-old hard working mother, Margery C. dreams of graduating her two children from college someday and being able to build a strong house to shelter her family from any form of calamity. Those dreams are pushing her to improve her productivity to increase their income since her husband’s is still small and sporadic, being a small time laborer. 

Margery’s children are still young (three and seven years old) so she cannot do business away from them for now. With that, the loan she is requesting through ASHI will be used to start up a “sari-sari” (variety) store, which will be located in her own small house. Goods she plans to purchase for selling are the basic needs of people around their village. Proceeds of this will be used to improve their own life, little by little.

loans.use: To purchase goods to sell in her store.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is a loving mother to her three children whose ages are from nine to 15 years old. The welfare of her family, especially her children, is her main priority above anything else. She joined ASHI with the support of her husband because she believes that through ASHI, loans she can avail will enable her to have her own business. This will provide her with the finances she needs to support the achievement of her dream. However, being a newly recognized member of ASHI, the Kiva field partner in the Philippines, Josephine understood that the amount of loan she can initially request is not that big yet. However, this will be used accordingly, in a hog/pig fattening business to have a profit when it will be sold after four months either by slaughtering or alive. 

Just like other poor mothers, Josephine is not dreaming for more than her children graduating from college and living a life than is not under the umbrella of poverty.  Profits of her business will be her great means of achieving such in addition to the financial support that her husband can provide her sporadically.
